+CrashCourse, . At time 4:47: I am sorry, but the way you wrote Bernoulli's Principle is incorrect. Correctly stated it says that as the speed changes (acceleration) along the flow (from one place to another due to diameter changes) the pressure changes (inversely). .. The way you stated it, pushing some fluid through a constant diameter pipe at a faster speed at a later time, means the pressure will be lower and this is simply untrue.  With no viscosity the internal pressure depends only on the system pressure and that can be anything and the velocity can also be anything. ... Also, Bernoulli did not develop that equation.  He only realized the inverse relationship between velocity and static pressure long a uniform flow. He defined no values, just that there was a pressure change accompanying a velocity change (acceleration) with absolutely no statement about cause and effect. ... It was Euler that realized the fact that it is the pressure gradient that is the accelerating force in fluids.  Pressure gradient is the cause of acceleration pushing fluid from higher pressure to lower pressure regions..  Newton for fluids.

What's true for water here, is also true for the air ducts ventilating your office or home. HVAC workers (usually) take great care to make sure the air duct's geometry remains constant through the entire duct. CAD programs are frequently used to help engineer consistent flow, and stamp out the parts on a plasma or laser CAM. I can't help but think of the What If entry for "What would happen if one tried to funnel Niagara Falls through a straw?"  "The flow rate over Niagara Falls is at least 100,000 cubic feet per second, which is actually mandated by law...A typical straw is about 7mm in diameter. To find out how fast the water flows, we just divide the flow rate by that area. If the result is greater than the speed of sound, our flow will probably be choked, which will lead to problems.  (Math here)  Apparently, our water will be going one-quarter of the speed of light."

No, Laminar flow just means that there is no turbulence in the flow rate. The stream lines are consistent and never cross. It does not negate that the molecules in the water are exerting pressure on their container. In fact the definition of a fluid is characterized by its ability to conform to a container and its ability to exert force perpendicularly to the surface of said container. Thus, you can have laminar flow and pressure against the walls of the pipe, because perpendicular pressure is in the nature of the fluids.
And where you saw streamlines crossing? Just curious.
You*

Kind of. A superfluid would have no viscosity, so thats nice. But it turns out to get all kinds of wierd behaviors that a  idealized fluid does not have.  If you stirred a superfluid just a little, it would basically keep the vortex forever. This could give you all kinds of problems with making the flow laminar. It also has a bunch of other messy properties that I dont really understand.  Water is actually the best approximation we can easily get our hands on. As long as its not moving to fast, it's behaving quite close a idealized fluid. Thats why these equations are so usefull in the first place.  But if you want to use it as a idealized fluid, study something called "Reynolds number". If that gets to high, you can kiss your laminar flow goodbye, and welcome your new viscosity overlord.
No. Nothing with mass can reach the speed of light.

We are still using whats commonly called newtonian physics. Basically human-scaled stuff.  If you start reducing the area to much, you get issues with making the atoms flow into the opening. And if you start increasing the speed to much, you get into whats called relativity.  As long as we are talking about areas and speeds that humans get to deal with in their daily lives, these issues can usually be ignored, so we will do that for now.

Yes. That basically means that the theory of fluid dynamics is not perfect for very small scales. On the other hand, this theory works well for scales above a few micrometers. If you go across that limit you will get to a another branch of physics, micro fluid dynamics, and its very relevant for biophysics and fluid in cells!

Just one thing, be careful when saying that the flow is LAMINAR and the fluid has NO VISCOSITY. The parameter which defines weather the flow is laminar or turbulent is named the Reynolds number. This parameter can be translated as the ration between inertial and viscous forces and, even though it is still difficult to identify/model the transition between flow regimes, it is known that higher Reynolds number correspond to turbulent flows and lower ones to laminar flows.  If we then "decrease" a fluid viscosity, the Reynolds number will increase , making the flow a turbulent one. The limit would be when viscosity is, like you assumed, zero. In this case the Reynolds number should be infinite, and one would incorrectly conclude that the flow is turbulent!  In fact, when viscosity is zero the flow is in fact called a potential flow (some more characteristics would be required but these ones do not go against any of your explanation). This kind of flow is described by the Laplace equation and not the usual Navier-Stokes equation.  Hope you don't take this correction the wrong way, but I've been working in fluid mechanics for a while and the topic of viscosity and flow regime is often confusing to someone learning it for the first time.  Love your movies, keep the good work!!!!!  P.S: Make a video on turbulence. It's a difficult subject but is definitely one of the most interesting  (I'm a bit bias since its the topic of my master thesis)

Hi! There are many times we look at doing this, but with limited time and our budget, it is often much more cost effective to do the animation. Sometimes we'll do examples (we've got one coming up with a water drinking bird toy thing) but sometimes it just doesn't work out. ALSO, a lot of these examples would need to be done in "perfect" environments to make sure everything works the way it's supposed to. We had this problem when we filmed the Chemistry series. "This SHOULD work, but it doesn't because a, b, c..." and by the time we've fixed a, b, and c, this experiment has gone from a 20 minute thing to a 2 hour thing.  Hope that helps :)   Nick J.

The description of Bernoulli's principle and how it relates to pressure is super misleading.  Just because a pipe is at low pressure doesn't mean that the velocity in the pipe is high.  The only way this is true is if you are comparing the condition at one point in the pipe to conditions at another point in the pipe.  The way it was stated and shown in the video makes it look like you could have two unrelated pipes and just by having them at different pressures you could have different flows.  Bernoulli's principle is much easier to understand if you talk about how the change in pressure relates to the change in velocity, height, and cross sectional area.

Pressure is molecules hitting the walls. The molecules all move in random direction normally, but if you make them move down the pipe, they don't hit the walls as much.  You're relieving the pressure by letting liquid move rather than trapping it in one place.

For the sake of simplicity, let us look at a single molecule. Imagine a single dot representing a molecule of some sort of gas. And Imagine it leaves a red trail wherever it goes. If i were to release him at the start of a 10 meter pipe with no initial velocity, you'll see the red line darting randomly in all directions, changing direction whenever it hits the wall. You will be able to notice that the line changed direction many times before finding its way out of the pipe. Now, let us shoot a gas molecule from the start of the pipe in a straight line in the direction of the end of the pipe. The molecule will still hit the walls a couple of times, and if you'd actually count the contact points of the red line, he will averagely almost hit the walls the same amount of times per second as the first experiment. But, because he moves down the pipe faster, he stays in one place far less, and he hits the wall far fewer times because he just rushes out of the pipe before even getting the chance to bounce around. Which means each molecule will spread their force to a wider area, while that force is staying not affected by the initial velocity we gave it (as it is perpendicular to the pipe in all directions). Pressure is a mesurement of how much force the molecules exert on their sorrounding when they interact. In a pipe the behavior of the pressure is unintuitive because you push the molecules to the only direction they won't feel much resistance, and cause them to interact less with the pipe (perpendicular velocity). [btw, all this stands only for a straight pipe, when you actually make a turn, velocity might cause a lot of force being applied to the turning point]

In this case, think of the fluid pressure the same as with a gas. It's the pressure pushing on the walls, not the water's velocity when it comes out of the pipe. Low speed high pressure. High speed low pressure.

The water always has velocity. It's made up of h20 molecules that constantly bounce around (faster when they're hot). When the velocities are all random and cancel each other out, the water is just sitting there. When most of them are moving in one direction, the water is moving. If most of the molecules are moving along the pipe, they're not bashing into the walls, which is what pressure is.

Unless your tower is a 100ft tall barrel, the legs of the tower doesn't count towards the spouting distance. The most you'll get is the distance from the top of the water surface in the tank to the nozzle on the tank.

No no, the legs absolutely count! That's why they put reservoirs in towers like that in the first place. The catch is just that there are losses between the tower and the end of your hose. Like how when Shini was playing with her hose the water dribbled out slow and wide at first, then shot out faster when she narrowed the outlet with her thumb. There are effects like that all along the path that limit the maximum speed of the water. 100ft is just the maximum height in an ideal model.

Hmm, but since acceleration due to gravity is constant, wouldn't the speed of the water exiting the tower nozzle be the same regardless how high the tower leg beyond a certain height? Isn't that why when OP points his hose skywards, the spout is not gonna go any where near 100ft.

Quantum mechanics:  the physics and math used to describe the electro-dynamic cloud  (the electrical thing that is moving) about the proton of an atom.  As a young undergraduate physics student, you learn a few things about this subject that blow your mind (really, you're not quite the same after you learn this).  First off, you learn some rather advanced methods of solving equations.  And you learn that you can create equations that describe systems that are so complicated, that you cannot solve the equation with a pencil and paper by hand --- without making significant simplifications, mathematical analogies, really -- the most clever physicists are really good at making these mathematical analogies; Richard Feynman, for instance, was one of these people, before he died of cancer in 1988.  One of these equations is a little thing called the Schroedinger Wave equation.  The Schroedinger Wave equation can be used (read:  is used) to describe the behavior of the electro-dynamic cloud that surrounds the nucleus of any atom.  There is only one instance in which, the Schroedinger Wave equation can be solved by hand (read: without the use of computers); and that is for the Hydrogen atom.  The reason for this is simple, the hydrogen atom is simple --- it has 1 proton, and 1 electron (which is not a particle, actually, it's more of a wibbly-wobbly fluid-wave-like thing --- which 'Wave Equations' are really good at describing).  The first, most important lesson regarding why we care about doing this is because we can use the solutions to these equations to describe the way that light will interact with the electron cloud surrounding the atoms.  Hydrogen absorbs and reflects light at different wavelengths (it reacts differently with differently 'colored' light  -- ie, hydrogen will absorb red light differently from how it absorbs blue light).  Being able to predict and describe this kind of thing allows a person to construct or put together different types of materials to create things like, new types of lasers, design new materials to be used in LEDs (and thereby light their bedroom, on a 6 Watt LED rather than with a 60 Watt traditional lightbulb, thereby using 10x less energy to light their house).  It also gives you a schematic and a guide to tell you how a material will react if you bombard it with energy in different ways.  (Like what happens if you physically 'hit' it with something; what happens if you heat it a certain way)  Things like this.  As for relativity:  Talk to someone else.  I admit that I find Quantum Mechanics more interesting than Relativity (but it's only because we can actually do more with Quantum Mechanics right now than General Relativity -- as far as I know, chalk this sentiment up to a hole in my personal education  -- if the combination of the two led to an advancement like anti-gravity some 200 years into the future; I would have to roll over in my grave, smile, then eat my socks).

The theorem only applies in the idealized case where the diameter of the barrel is infinitely larger than the pipe, so that we can cancel the (1/2)*\rho*v^2_{top} term. Or equivalently, the statement is more correct the smaller the pipe diameter is.

Fluid Mechanics are on AP Physics 2, not AP Physics 1. On an unrelated note, AP Physics 1 topics are all discussed well in AP Physics 1 Essentials by Dan Fullerton.
Okay but what book does crashcourse use

Abhimaster2001 No, no, no. They don't have a Physics Bible to follow. Any Calculus-based Introductory Physics textbook goes over everything they talk about, only in much more detail. My Physics textbook, Fundamentals of Physics by David Halliday, is sought to be one of the hardest introductory Physics textbooks, going over Classical Mechanics, Thermodynamics, Electricity & Magnetism, Optics, and Modern Physics with lots of very difficult mathematical Physics problems. Their lessons are supposed to coincide with the AP Physics 1 & 2 framework (which is weird, considering neither course has Calculus or goes over Statics and Equilibrium). So if you were to go to Collegeboard, then the Big Ideas should give you insight on what they intend to teach.
